body: Good catch! Would you be interested in submitting a PR?

Calling `File#setWritable(true)` on all files before deleting them?

What if [ACL's](https://github.com/sormuras/bach/blob/d891bd5c32be282ff5f259267041f366bdd40c72/deprecated/src-20190228/test/Util.java#L15-L55) are used to prevent access to files within the temporary directory?

A solution could be to just log a warning when a temporary could not be deleted, instead of the entire stack trace.

My immediate thought was `File#setWritable`, however `Path -> File` conversion might take time.

So it should probably be guarded with `Files#isWritable(Path)`.
Then I'm not sure what to do. Either try the new shiny `java.nio.file.Files#getFileAttributeView` (which should probably support ACL) or resort to an old `File.setWritable`.

Frankly speaking, I've no much experience in that area and I just hoped you have much more.

>A solution could be to just log a warning when a temporary could not be deleted, instead of the entire stack trace.

The stacktrace does not really hurt in my opinion.

PS. What do you think of making one more talk for Heisenbug? :)

> Calling File#setWritable(true) on all files before deleting them?

Did you mean to call `setWritable` in case the delete fails?

> PS. What do you think of making one more talk for Heisenbug? :)

(-:

> Did you mean to call `setWritable` in case the delete fails?

Yeah, at least we could try to do that before failing. But I'm not sure the extension should do this at all -- it's up to the test leave the provided temporary directory in a "delete-able" state. The extension should not perform "force delete" action, imho.
I think it should attempt to delete "undeletable" files if the initial delete fails. If we need to convert `Path` to `File` for that I think that would be ok.

The implementer would need to remember to catch the potential exception thrown by `Path::toFile` though, in case the user of the extension decided to use e.g. JimFS rather than the on-disk filesystem. :)

> I think it should attempt to delete "undeletable" files if the initial delete fails

I agree. The test might fail in the middle (e.g. after creating a read-only file), so it would be nice if the framework tries to use set writable.

>If we need to convert Path to File for that I think that would be ok.

Performance-wise it would be ok. However, I'm not sure File could handle ACLs. On the other hand, dealing with ACLs should probably be postponed until someone manages to craft that test case.

issue.title: Remove read-only files under TempDir

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Removal of read-only files fails (e.g. for Windows),
so the engine should try making the file writable first.

see #2046

issue.title: TempDir fails to cleanup if directory was made read-only

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Similar to #2046, but this is on Linux with JUnit 5.6.0.

If the temporary directory is read-only and not empty, then the cleanup fails.

```java
@Test
public void readOnly(@TempDir File tempDir) throws IOException {
    File file = tempDir.toPath().resolve("file").toFile();
    assumeTrue(file.createNewFile());
    assumeTrue(tempDir.setReadOnly());
    assumeTrue(file.setReadOnly());
}
```

issue.title: Bump junit to 5.6.2 to better support TempDir on Windows

repository.name: rpm-adapter
repository.description: Turns your data storage into an RPM repository

issue.body:
Many of our test fails on Windows, and in some case, it is caused by `TempDir` not succeeding in deleting a temporary directory used for test.

In particular I've seen https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2046, in:
- #95 #96 even though there are other problems related to #86 happening there too...
- #100 where it happens directly without reason 

Latest version of junit should include the fix.
